939987 [183] Alexey Fyodorovitch Karamazov was the third son of Fyodor Pavlovitch
939987 [184] Karamazov, a land owner well known in our district in his own day, and
939987 [185] still remembered among us owing to his gloomy and tragic death, which
939987 [186] happened thirteen years ago, and which I shall describe in its proper
939987 [187] place. For the present I will only say that this â€œlandownerâ€â€”for so we
939987 [188] used to call him, although he hardly spent a day of his life on his own
939987 [189] estateâ€”was a strange type, yet one pretty frequently to be met with, a
939987 [190] type abject and vicious and at the same time senseless. But he was one of
939987 [191] those senseless persons who are very well capable of looking after their
939987 [192] worldly affairs, and, apparently, after nothing else. Fyodor Pavlovitch,
939987 [193] for instance, began with next to nothing; his estate was of the smallest;
939987 [194] he ran to dine at other menâ€™s tables, and fastened on them as a toady, yet
939987 [195] at his death it appeared that he had a hundred thousand roubles in hard
939987 [196] cash. At the same time, he was all his life one of the most senseless,
939987 [197] fantastical fellows in the whole district. I repeat, it was not
939987 [198] stupidityâ€”the majority of these fantastical fellows are shrewd and
939987 [199] intelligent enoughâ€”but just senselessness, and a peculiar national form of
939987 [200] it.
939987 [201] 
939987 [202] He was married twice, and had three sons, the eldest, Dmitri, by his first
939987 [203] wife, and two, Ivan and Alexey, by his second. Fyodor Pavlovitchâ€™s first
939987 [204] wife, AdelaÃ¯da Ivanovna, belonged to a fairly rich and distinguished noble
939987 [205] family, also landowners in our district, the MiÃ¼sovs. How it came to pass
939987 [206] that an heiress, who was also a beauty, and moreover one of those
939987 [207] vigorous, intelligent girls, so common in this generation, but sometimes
939987 [208] also to be found in the last, could have married such a worthless, puny
939987 [209] weakling, as we all called him, I wonâ€™t attempt to explain. I knew a young
939987 [210] lady of the last â€œromanticâ€ generation who after some years of an
939987 [211] enigmatic passion for a gentleman, whom she might quite easily have
939987 [212] married at any moment, invented insuperable obstacles to their union, and
939987 [213] ended by throwing herself one stormy night into a rather deep and rapid
939987 [214] river from a high bank, almost a precipice, and so perished, entirely to
939987 [215] satisfy her own caprice, and to be like Shakespeareâ€™s Ophelia. Indeed, if
939987 [216] this precipice, a chosen and favorite spot of hers, had been less
939987 [217] picturesque, if there had been a prosaic flat bank in its place, most
939987 [218] likely the suicide would never have taken place. This is a fact, and
939987 [219] probably there have been not a few similar instances in the last two or
939987 [220] three generations. AdelaÃ¯da Ivanovna MiÃ¼sovâ€™s action was similarly, no
939987 [221] doubt, an echo of other peopleâ€™s ideas, and was due to the irritation
939987 [222] caused by lack of mental freedom. She wanted, perhaps, to show her
939987 [223] feminine independence, to override class distinctions and the despotism of
939987 [224] her family. And a pliable imagination persuaded her, we must suppose, for
939987 [225] a brief moment, that Fyodor Pavlovitch, in spite of his parasitic
939987 [226] position, was one of the bold and ironical spirits of that progressive
939987 [227] epoch, though he was, in fact, an ill-natured buffoon and nothing more.
939987 [228] What gave the marriage piquancy was that it was preceded by an elopement,
939987 [229] and this greatly captivated AdelaÃ¯da Ivanovnaâ€™s fancy. Fyodor Pavlovitchâ€™s
939987 [230] position at the time made him specially eager for any such enterprise, for
939987 [231] he was passionately anxious to make a career in one way or another. To
939987 [232] attach himself to a good family and obtain a dowry was an alluring
939987 [233] prospect. As for mutual love it did not exist apparently, either in the
939987 [234] bride or in him, in spite of AdelaÃ¯da Ivanovnaâ€™s beauty. This was,
939987 [235] perhaps, a unique case of the kind in the life of Fyodor Pavlovitch, who
939987 [236] was always of a voluptuous temper, and ready to run after any petticoat on
939987 [237] the slightest encouragement. She seems to have been the only woman who
939987 [238] made no particular appeal to his senses.
939987 [239] 
939987 [240] Immediately after the elopement AdelaÃ¯da Ivanovna discerned in a flash
939987 [241] that she had no feeling for her husband but contempt. The marriage
939987 [242] accordingly showed itself in its true colors with extraordinary rapidity.
939987 [243] Although the family accepted the event pretty quickly and apportioned the

939987 [264] used to drive all over the province, complaining tearfully to each and all

939987 [266] for a husband to mention in regard to his own married life. What seemed to

939987 [269] 
939987 [270] â€œOne would think that youâ€™d got a promotion, Fyodor Pavlovitch, you seem

939987 [283] received the news of her death in Petersburg. She had died quite suddenly

939987 [285] it, of starvation. Fyodor Pavlovitch was drunk when he heard of his wifeâ€™s
939987 [286] death, and the story is that he ran out into the street and began shouting
939987 [287] with joy, raising his hands to Heaven: â€œLord, now lettest Thou Thy servant
939987 [288] depart in peace,â€ but others say he wept without restraint like a little
939987 [289] child, so much so that people were sorry for him, in spite of the
939987 [290] repulsion he inspired. It is quite possible that both versions were true,
939987 [291] that he rejoiced at his release, and at the same time wept for her who
939987 [292] released him. As a general rule, people, even the wicked, are much more
939987 [293] naÃ¯ve and simple-hearted than we suppose. And we ourselves are, too.

939987 [300] You can easily imagine what a father such a man could be and how he would
939987 [301] bring up his children. His behavior as a father was exactly what might be

939987 [304] simply because he forgot him. While he was wearying every one with his

939987 [307] into his care. If he hadnâ€™t looked after him there would have been no one

939987 [309] 
939987 [310] It happened moreover that the childâ€™s relations on his motherâ€™s side

939987 [348] Fyodor Pavlovitch was all his life fond of acting, of suddenly playing an

939987 [930] Some of my readers may imagine that my young man was a sickly, ecstatic,

939987 [938] that Alyosha was more of a realist than any one. Oh! no doubt, in the
939987 [939] monastery he fully believed in miracles, but, to my thinking, miracles are
939987 [940] never a stumbling-block to the realist. It is not miracles that dispose
939987 [941] realists to belief. The genuine realist, if he is an unbeliever, will
939987 [942] always find strength and ability to disbelieve in the miraculous, and if
939987 [943] he is confronted with a miracle as an irrefutable fact he would rather
939987 [944] disbelieve his own senses than admit the fact. Even if he admits it, he
939987 [945] admits it as a fact of nature till then unrecognized by him. Faith does
939987 [946] not, in the realist, spring from the miracle but the miracle from faith.
939987 [947] If the realist once believes, then he is bound by his very realism to
939987 [948] admit the miraculous also. The Apostle Thomas said that he would not
939987 [949] believe till he saw, but when he did see he said, â€œMy Lord and my God!â€

939987 [1016] What was such an elder? An elder was one who took your soul, your will,
939987 [1017] into his soul and his will. When you choose an elder, you renounce your
939987 [1018] own will and yield it to him in complete submission, complete
939987 [1019] self-abnegation. This novitiate, this terrible school of abnegation, is
939987 [1020] undertaken voluntarily, in the hope of self-conquest, of self-mastery, in
939987 [1021] order, after a life of obedience, to attain perfect freedom, that is, from
939987 [1022] self; to escape the lot of those who have lived their whole life without
939987 [1023] finding their true selves in themselves. This institution of elders is not
939987 [1024] founded on theory, but was established in the East from the practice of a
939987 [1025] thousand years. The obligations due to an elder are not the ordinary
939987 [1026] â€œobedienceâ€ which has always existed in our Russian monasteries. The
939987 [1027] obligation involves confession to the elder by all who have submitted
939987 [1028] themselves to him, and to the indissoluble bond between him and them.

939987 [1030] The story is told, for instance, that in the early days of Christianity

939987 [12771] Beloved fathers and teachers, I was born in a distant province in the
939987 [12772] north, in the town of V. My father was a gentleman by birth, but of no
939987 [12773] great consequence or position. He died when I was only two years old, and
939987 [12774] I donâ€™t remember him at all. He left my mother a small house built of
939987 [12775] wood, and a fortune, not large, but sufficient to keep her and her
939987 [12776] children in comfort. There were two of us, my elder brother Markel and I.
939987 [12777] He was eight years older than I was, of hasty irritable temperament, but
939987 [12778] kind-hearted and never ironical. He was remarkably silent, especially at
939987 [12779] home with me, his mother, and the servants. He did well at school, but did
939987 [12780] not get on with his schoolfellows, though he never quarreled, at least so
939987 [12781] my mother has told me. Six months before his death, when he was seventeen,

939987 [14067] _(e) The Russian Monk and his possible Significance_

939987 [14434] _(h) Can a Man judge his Fellow Creatures? Faith to the End_

939987 [14436] Remember particularly that you cannot be a judge of any one. For no one

939987 [14500] _(i) Of Hell and Hell Fire, a Mystic Reflection_
939987 [14501] 
939987 [14502] Fathers and teachers, I ponder, â€œWhat is hell?â€ I maintain that it is the

939987 [14534] for responsive, active and grateful love which is now impossible. In the

939987 [14536] impossibility would serve at last to console them. For accepting the love

939987 [14539] as it were, to a certain semblance of that active love which they scorned

939987 [14541] and brothers, that I cannot express this clearly. But woe to those who
939987 [14542] have slain themselves on earth, woe to the suicides! I believe that there
939987 [14543] can be none more miserable then they. They tell us that it is a sin to
939987 [14544] pray for them and outwardly the Church, as it were, renounces them, but in
939987 [14545] my secret heart I believe that we may pray even for them. Love can never
939987 [14546] be an offense to Christ. For such as those I have prayed inwardly all my
939987 [14547] life, I confess it, fathers and teachers, and even now I pray for them
939987 [14548] every day.
939987 [14549] 
939987 [14550] Oh, there are some who remain proud and fierce even in hell, in spite of
939987 [14551] their certain knowledge and contemplation of the absolute truth; there are
939987 [14552] some fearful ones who have given themselves over to Satan and his proud
939987 [14553] spirit entirely. For such, hell is voluntary and ever consuming; they are
939987 [14554] tortured by their own choice. For they have cursed themselves, cursing God
939987 [14555] and life. They live upon their vindictive pride like a starving man in the
939987 [14556] desert sucking blood out of his own body. But they are never satisfied,
939987 [14557] and they refuse forgiveness, they curse God Who calls them. They cannot
939987 [14558] behold the living God without hatred, and they cry out that the God of
939987 [14559] life should be annihilated, that God should destroy Himself and His own
939987 [14560] creation. And they will burn in the fire of their own wrath for ever and
939987 [14561] yearn for death and annihilation. But they will not attain to death....

939987 [35903] boys, from this day forth, I have a place in my heart for you all, and I
939987 [35904] beg you to keep a place in your hearts for me! Well, and who has united us
939987 [35905] in this kind, good feeling which we shall remember and intend to remember

939987 [35908] hearts from this time forth!â€

939987 [35910] â€œYes, yes, for ever, for ever!â€ the boys cried in their ringing voices,
939987 [35911] with softened faces.

939987 [35927] â€œKaramazov, we love you!â€ a voice, probably Kartashovâ€™s, cried

939987 [35930] â€œWe love you, we love you!â€ they all caught it up. There were tears in the

939987 [35935] â€œAnd may the dead boyâ€™s memory live for ever!â€ Alyosha added again with

939987 [35939] 
939987 [35940] â€œKaramazov,â€ cried Kolya, â€œcan it be true whatâ€™s taught us in religion,

939987 [35943] 
939987 [35944] â€œCertainly we shall all rise again, certainly we shall see each other and

939987 [35946] Alyosha answered, half laughing, half enthusiastic.

939987 [35948] â€œAh, how splendid it will be!â€ broke from Kolya.

939987 [36510] CRIME AND PUNISHMENT
939987 [36511] 
939987 [36512] By Fyodor Dostoevsky
939987 [36513] 
939987 [36514] 
939987 [36515] 
939987 [36516] Translated By Constance Garnett
939987 [36517] 
939987 [36518] 
939987 [36519] 
939987 [36520] 
939987 [36521] TRANSLATOR'S PREFACE
939987 [36522] 
939987 [36523] A few words about Dostoevsky himself may help the English reader to
939987 [36524] understand his work.
939987 [36525] 
939987 [36526] Dostoevsky was the son of a doctor. His parents were very hard-working
939987 [36527] and deeply religious people, but so poor that they lived with their five
939987 [36528] children in only two rooms. The father and mother spent their evenings
939987 [36529] in reading aloud to their children, generally from books of a serious
939987 [36530] character.
939987 [36531] 
939987 [36532] Though always sickly and delicate Dostoevsky came out third in the
939987 [36533] final examination of the Petersburg school of Engineering. There he had
939987 [36534] already begun his first work, "Poor Folk."
939987 [36535] 
939987 [36536] This story was published by the poet Nekrassov in his review and
939987 [36537] was received with acclamations. The shy, unknown youth found himself
939987 [36538] instantly something of a celebrity. A brilliant and successful career
939987 [36539] seemed to open before him, but those hopes were soon dashed. In 1849 he
939987 [36540] was arrested.
939987 [36541] 
939987 [36542] Though neither by temperament nor conviction a revolutionist, Dostoevsky
939987 [36543] was one of a little group of young men who met together to read Fourier
939987 [36544] and Proudhon. He was accused of "taking part in conversations against
939987 [36545] the censorship, of reading a letter from Byelinsky to Gogol, and of
939987 [36546] knowing of the intention to set up a printing press." Under Nicholas
939987 [36547] I. (that "stern and just man," as Maurice Baring calls him) this was
939987 [36548] enough, and he was condemned to death. After eight months' imprisonment
939987 [36549] he was with twenty-one others taken out to the Semyonovsky Square to
939987 [36550] be shot. Writing to his brother Mihail, Dostoevsky says: "They snapped
939987 [36551] words over our heads, and they made us put on the white shirts worn by
939987 [36552] persons condemned to death. Thereupon we were bound in threes to stakes,
939987 [36553] to suffer execution. Being the third in the row, I concluded I had only
939987 [36554] a few minutes of life before me. I thought of you and your dear ones and
939987 [36555] I contrived to kiss Plestcheiev and Dourov, who were next to me, and to
939987 [36556] bid them farewell. Suddenly the troops beat a tattoo, we were unbound,
939987 [36557] brought back upon the scaffold, and informed that his Majesty had spared
939987 [36558] us our lives." The sentence was commuted to hard labour.
939987 [36559] 
939987 [36560] One of the prisoners, Grigoryev, went mad as soon as he was untied, and
939987 [36561] never regained his sanity.
939987 [36562] 
939987 [36563] The intense suffering of this experience left a lasting stamp on
939987 [36564] Dostoevsky's mind. Though his religious temper led him in the end to
939987 [36565] accept every suffering with resignation and to regard it as a blessing
939987 [36566] in his own case, he constantly recurs to the subject in his writings.
939987 [36567] He describes the awful agony of the condemned man and insists on the
939987 [36568] cruelty of inflicting such torture. Then followed four years of penal
939987 [36569] servitude, spent in the company of common criminals in Siberia, where
939987 [36570] he began the "Dead House," and some years of service in a disciplinary
939987 [36571] battalion.
939987 [36572] 
939987 [36573] He had shown signs of some obscure nervous disease before his arrest
939987 [36574] and this now developed into violent attacks of epilepsy, from which he
939987 [36575] suffered for the rest of his life. The fits occurred three or four times
939987 [36576] a year and were more frequent in periods of great strain. In 1859 he was
939987 [36577] allowed to return to Russia. He started a journal--"Vremya," which was
939987 [36578] forbidden by the Censorship through a misunderstanding. In 1864 he lost
939987 [36579] his first wife and his brother Mihail. He was in terrible poverty, yet
939987 [36580] he took upon himself the payment of his brother's debts. He started
939987 [36581] another journal--"The Epoch," which within a few months was also
939987 [36582] prohibited. He was weighed down by debt, his brother's family was
939987 [36583] dependent on him, he was forced to write at heart-breaking speed, and is
939987 [36584] said never to have corrected his work. The later years of his life were
939987 [36585] much softened by the tenderness and devotion of his second wife.
939987 [36586] 
939987 [36587] In June 1880 he made his famous speech at the unveiling of the
939987 [36588] monument to Pushkin in Moscow and he was received with extraordinary
939987 [36589] demonstrations of love and honour.
939987 [36590] 
939987 [36591] A few months later Dostoevsky died. He was followed to the grave by a
939987 [36592] vast multitude of mourners, who "gave the hapless man the funeral of a
939987 [36593] king." He is still probably the most widely read writer in Russia.
939987 [36594] 
939987 [36595] In the words of a Russian critic, who seeks to explain the feeling
939987 [36596] inspired by Dostoevsky: "He was one of ourselves, a man of our blood and
939987 [36597] our bone, but one who has suffered and has seen so much more deeply than
939987 [36598] we have his insight impresses us as wisdom... that wisdom of the heart
939987 [36599] which we seek that we may learn from it how to live. All his other
939987 [36600] gifts came to him from nature, this he won for himself and through it he
939987 [36601] became great."
939987 [36602] 
939987 [36603] 
939987 [36604] 
939987 [36605] 
939987 [36606] 
939987 [36607] CRIME AND PUNISHMENT
939987 [36608] 
939987 [36609] 
939987 [36610] 
939987 [36611] 
939987 [36612] PART I
939987 [36613] 
939987 [36614] 
939987 [36615] 
939987 [36616] CHAPTER I
939987 [36617] 
939987 [36618] On an exceptionally hot evening early in July a young man came out of
939987 [36619] the garret in which he lodged in S. Place and walked slowly, as though
939987 [36620] in hesitation, towards K. bridge.
939987 [36621] 
939987 [36622] He had successfully avoided meeting his landlady on the staircase. His
939987 [36623] garret was under the roof of a high, five-storied house and was more
939987 [36624] like a cupboard than a room. The landlady who provided him with garret,
939987 [36625] dinners, and attendance, lived on the floor below, and every time
939987 [36626] he went out he was obliged to pass her kitchen, the door of which
939987 [36627] invariably stood open. And each time he passed, the young man had a
939987 [36628] sick, frightened feeling, which made him scowl and feel ashamed. He was
939987 [36629] hopelessly in debt to his landlady, and was afraid of meeting her.
939987 [36630] 
939987 [36631] This was not because he was cowardly and abject, quite the contrary; but
939987 [36632] for some time past he had been in an overstrained irritable condition,
939987 [36633] verging on hypochondria. He had become so completely absorbed in
939987 [36634] himself, and isolated from his fellows that he dreaded meeting, not
939987 [36635] only his landlady, but anyone at all. He was crushed by poverty, but the
939987 [36636] anxieties of his position had of late ceased to weigh upon him. He had
939987 [36637] given up attending to matters of practical importance; he had lost all
939987 [36638] desire to do so. Nothing that any landlady could do had a real terror
939987 [36639] for him. But to be stopped on the stairs, to be forced to listen to her
939987 [36640] trivial, irrelevant gossip, to pestering demands for payment, threats
939987 [36641] and complaints, and to rack his brains for excuses, to prevaricate, to
939987 [36642] lie--no, rather than that, he would creep down the stairs like a cat and
939987 [36643] slip out unseen.
939987 [36644] 
939987 [36645] This evening, however, on coming out into the street, he became acutely
939987 [36646] aware of his fears.
939987 [36647] 
939987 [36648] "I want to attempt a thing _like that_ and am frightened by these
939987 [36649] trifles," he thought, with an odd smile. "Hm... yes, all is in a man's
939987 [36650] hands and he lets it all slip from cowardice, that's an axiom. It would
939987 [36651] be interesting to know what it is men are most afraid of. Taking a new
939987 [36652] step, uttering a new word is what they fear most.... But I am talking
939987 [36653] too much. It's because I chatter that I do nothing. Or perhaps it is
939987 [36654] that I chatter because I do nothing. I've learned to chatter this
939987 [36655] last month, lying for days together in my den thinking... of Jack the
939987 [36656] Giant-killer. Why am I going there now? Am I capable of _that_? Is
939987 [36657] _that_ serious? It is not serious at all. It's simply a fantasy to amuse
939987 [36658] myself; a plaything! Yes, maybe it is a plaything."
939987 [36659] 
939987 [36660] The heat in the street was terrible: and the airlessness, the bustle
939987 [36661] and the plaster, scaffolding, bricks, and dust all about him, and that
939987 [36662] special Petersburg stench, so familiar to all who are unable to get out
939987 [36663] of town in summer--all worked painfully upon the young man's already
939987 [36664] overwrought nerves. The insufferable stench from the pot-houses, which
939987 [36665] are particularly numerous in that part of the town, and the drunken men
939987 [36666] whom he met continually, although it was a working day, completed
939987 [36667] the revolting misery of the picture. An expression of the profoundest
939987 [36668] disgust gleamed for a moment in the young man's refined face. He was,
939987 [36669] by the way, exceptionally handsome, above the average in height, slim,
939987 [36670] well-built, with beautiful dark eyes and dark brown hair. Soon he sank
939987 [36671] into deep thought, or more accurately speaking into a complete blankness
939987 [36672] of mind; he walked along not observing what was about him and not caring
939987 [36673] to observe it. From time to time, he would mutter something, from the
939987 [36674] habit of talking to himself, to which he had just confessed. At these
939987 [36675] moments he would become conscious that his ideas were sometimes in a
939987 [36676] tangle and that he was very weak; for two days he had scarcely tasted
939987 [36677] food.
939987 [36678] 
939987 [36679] He was so badly dressed that even a man accustomed to shabbiness would
939987 [36680] have been ashamed to be seen in the street in such rags. In that quarter
939987 [36681] of the town, however, scarcely any shortcoming in dress would have
939987 [36682] created surprise. Owing to the proximity of the Hay Market, the number
939987 [36683] of establishments of bad character, the preponderance of the trading
939987 [36684] and working class population crowded in these streets and alleys in the
939987 [36685] heart of Petersburg, types so various were to be seen in the streets
939987 [36686] that no figure, however queer, would have caused surprise. But there was
939987 [36687] such accumulated bitterness and contempt in the young man's heart, that,
939987 [36688] in spite of all the fastidiousness of youth, he minded his rags least
939987 [36689] of all in the street. It was a different matter when he met with
939987 [36690] acquaintances or with former fellow students, whom, indeed, he disliked
939987 [36691] meeting at any time. And yet when a drunken man who, for some unknown
939987 [36692] reason, was being taken somewhere in a huge waggon dragged by a heavy
939987 [36693] dray horse, suddenly shouted at him as he drove past: "Hey there, German
939987 [36694] hatter" bawling at the top of his voice and pointing at him--the young
939987 [36695] man stopped suddenly and clutched tremulously at his hat. It was a tall
939987 [36696] round hat from Zimmerman's, but completely worn out, rusty with age, all
939987 [36697] torn and bespattered, brimless and bent on one side in a most unseemly
939987 [36698] fashion. Not shame, however, but quite another feeling akin to terror
939987 [36699] had overtaken him.
939987 [36700] 
939987 [36701] "I knew it," he muttered in confusion, "I thought so! That's the worst
939987 [36702] of all! Why, a stupid thing like this, the most trivial detail might
939987 [36703] spoil the whole plan. Yes, my hat is too noticeable.... It looks absurd
939987 [36704] and that makes it noticeable.... With my rags I ought to wear a cap, any
939987 [36705] sort of old pancake, but not this grotesque thing. Nobody wears such
939987 [36706] a hat, it would be noticed a mile off, it would be remembered.... What
939987 [36707] matters is that people would remember it, and that would give them
939987 [36708] a clue. For this business one should be as little conspicuous as
939987 [36709] possible.... Trifles, trifles are what matter! Why, it's just such
939987 [36710] trifles that always ruin everything...."
939987 [36711] 
939987 [36712] He had not far to go; he knew indeed how many steps it was from the gate
939987 [36713] of his lodging house: exactly seven hundred and thirty. He had counted
939987 [36714] them once when he had been lost in dreams. At the time he had put no
939987 [36715] faith in those dreams and was only tantalising himself by their hideous
939987 [36716] but daring recklessness. Now, a month later, he had begun to look upon
939987 [36717] them differently, and, in spite of the monologues in which he jeered at
939987 [36718] his own impotence and indecision, he had involuntarily come to regard
939987 [36719] this "hideous" dream as an exploit to be attempted, although he
939987 [36720] still did not realise this himself. He was positively going now for a
939987 [36721] "rehearsal" of his project, and at every step his excitement grew more
939987 [36722] and more violent.
939987 [36723] 
939987 [36724] With a sinking heart and a nervous tremor, he went up to a huge house
939987 [36725] which on one side looked on to the canal, and on the other into the
939987 [36726] street. This house was let out in tiny tenements and was inhabited by
939987 [36727] working people of all kinds--tailors, locksmiths, cooks, Germans of
939987 [36728] sorts, girls picking up a living as best they could, petty clerks, etc.
939987 [36729] There was a continual coming and going through the two gates and in the
939987 [36730] two courtyards of the house. Three or four door-keepers were employed on
939987 [36731] the building. The young man was very glad to meet none of them, and
939987 [36732] at once slipped unnoticed through the door on the right, and up the
939987 [36733] staircase. It was a back staircase, dark and narrow, but he was familiar
939987 [36734] with it already, and knew his way, and he liked all these surroundings:
939987 [36735] in such darkness even the most inquisitive eyes were not to be dreaded.
939987 [36736] 
939987 [36737] "If I am so scared now, what would it be if it somehow came to pass that
939987 [36738] I were really going to do it?" he could not help asking himself as he
939987 [36739] reached the fourth storey. There his progress was barred by some porters
939987 [36740] who were engaged in moving furniture out of a flat. He knew that the
939987 [36741] flat had been occupied by a German clerk in the civil service, and his
939987 [36742] family. This German was moving out then, and so the fourth floor on this
939987 [36743] staircase would be untenanted except by the old woman. "That's a good
939987 [36744] thing anyway," he thought to himself, as he rang the bell of the old
939987 [36745] woman's flat. The bell gave a faint tinkle as though it were made of
939987 [36746] tin and not of copper. The little flats in such houses always have bells
939987 [36747] that ring like that. He had forgotten the note of that bell, and now
939987 [36748] its peculiar tinkle seemed to remind him of something and to bring it
939987 [36749] clearly before him.... He started, his nerves were terribly overstrained
939987 [36750] by now. In a little while, the door was opened a tiny crack: the old
939987 [36751] woman eyed her visitor with evident distrust through the crack, and
939987 [36752] nothing could be seen but her little eyes, glittering in the darkness.
939987 [36753] But, seeing a number of people on the landing, she grew bolder, and
939987 [36754] opened the door wide. The young man stepped into the dark entry, which
939987 [36755] was partitioned off from the tiny kitchen. The old woman stood facing
939987 [36756] him in silence and looking inquiringly at him. She was a diminutive,
939987 [36757] withered up old woman of sixty, with sharp malignant eyes and a sharp
939987 [36758] little nose. Her colourless, somewhat grizzled hair was thickly smeared
939987 [36759] with oil, and she wore no kerchief over it. Round her thin long neck,
939987 [36760] which looked like a hen's leg, was knotted some sort of flannel rag,
939987 [36761] and, in spite of the heat, there hung flapping on her shoulders, a mangy
939987 [36762] fur cape, yellow with age. The old woman coughed and groaned at every
939987 [36763] instant. The young man must have looked at her with a rather peculiar
939987 [36764] expression, for a gleam of mistrust came into her eyes again.
939987 [36765] 
939987 [36766] "Raskolnikov, a student, I came here a month ago," the young man made
939987 [36767] haste to mutter, with a half bow, remembering that he ought to be more
939987 [36768] polite.
939987 [36769] 
939987 [36770] "I remember, my good sir, I remember quite well your coming here," the
939987 [36771] old woman said distinctly, still keeping her inquiring eyes on his face.
939987 [36772] 
939987 [36773] "And here... I am again on the same errand," Raskolnikov continued, a
939987 [36774] little disconcerted and surprised at the old woman's mistrust. "Perhaps
939987 [36775] she is always like that though, only I did not notice it the other
939987 [36776] time," he thought with an uneasy feeling.
939987 [36777] 
939987 [36778] The old woman paused, as though hesitating; then stepped on one side,
939987 [36779] and pointing to the door of the room, she said, letting her visitor pass
939987 [36780] in front of her:
939987 [36781] 
939987 [36782] "Step in, my good sir."
939987 [36783] 
939987 [36784] The little room into which the young man walked, with yellow paper on
939987 [36785] the walls, geraniums and muslin curtains in the windows, was brightly
939987 [36786] lighted up at that moment by the setting sun.
939987 [36787] 
939987 [36788] "So the sun will shine like this _then_ too!" flashed as it were by
939987 [36789] chance through Raskolnikov's mind, and with a rapid glance he scanned
939987 [36790] everything in the room, trying as far as possible to notice and
939987 [36791] remember its arrangement. But there was nothing special in the room. The
939987 [36792] furniture, all very old and of yellow wood, consisted of a sofa with
939987 [36793] a huge bent wooden back, an oval table in front of the sofa, a
939987 [36794] dressing-table with a looking-glass fixed on it between the windows,
939987 [36795] chairs along the walls and two or three half-penny prints in yellow
939987 [36796] frames, representing German damsels with birds in their hands--that was
939987 [36797] all. In the corner a light was burning before a small ikon. Everything
939987 [36798] was very clean; the floor and the furniture were brightly polished;
939987 [36799] everything shone.
939987 [36800] 
939987 [36801] "Lizaveta's work," thought the young man. There was not a speck of dust
939987 [36802] to be seen in the whole flat.
939987 [36803] 
939987 [36804] "It's in the houses of spiteful old widows that one finds such
939987 [36805] cleanliness," Raskolnikov thought again, and he stole a curious glance
939987 [36806] at the cotton curtain over the door leading into another tiny room, in
939987 [36807] which stood the old woman's bed and chest of drawers and into which he
939987 [36808] had never looked before. These two rooms made up the whole flat.
939987 [36809] 
939987 [36810] "What do you want?" the old woman said severely, coming into the room
939987 [36811] and, as before, standing in front of him so as to look him straight in
939987 [36812] the face.
939987 [36813] 
939987 [36814] "I've brought something to pawn here," and he drew out of his pocket
939987 [36815] an old-fashioned flat silver watch, on the back of which was engraved a
939987 [36816] globe; the chain was of steel.
939987 [36817] 
939987 [36818] "But the time is up for your last pledge. The month was up the day
939987 [36819] before yesterday."
939987 [36820] 
939987 [36821] "I will bring you the interest for another month; wait a little."
939987 [36822] 
939987 [36823] "But that's for me to do as I please, my good sir, to wait or to sell
939987 [36824] your pledge at once."
939987 [36825] 
939987 [36826] "How much will you give me for the watch, Alyona Ivanovna?"
939987 [36827] 
939987 [36828] "You come with such trifles, my good sir, it's scarcely worth anything.
939987 [36829] I gave you two roubles last time for your ring and one could buy it
939987 [36830] quite new at a jeweler's for a rouble and a half."
939987 [36831] 
939987 [36832] "Give me four roubles for it, I shall redeem it, it was my father's. I
939987 [36833] shall be getting some money soon."
939987 [36834] 
939987 [36835] "A rouble and a half, and interest in advance, if you like!"
939987 [36836] 
939987 [36837] "A rouble and a half!" cried the young man.
939987 [36838] 
939987 [36839] "Please yourself"--and the old woman handed him back the watch. The
939987 [36840] young man took it, and was so angry that he was on the point of going
939987 [36841] away; but checked himself at once, remembering that there was nowhere
939987 [36842] else he could go, and that he had had another object also in coming.
939987 [36843] 
939987 [36844] "Hand it over," he said roughly.
939987 [36845] 
939987 [36846] The old woman fumbled in her pocket for her keys, and disappeared behind
939987 [36847] the curtain into the other room. The young man, left standing alone in
939987 [36848] the middle of the room, listened inquisitively, thinking. He could hear
939987 [36849] her unlocking the chest of drawers.
939987 [36850] 
939987 [36851] "It must be the top drawer," he reflected. "So she carries the keys in
939987 [36852] a pocket on the right. All in one bunch on a steel ring.... And there's
939987 [36853] one key there, three times as big as all the others, with deep notches;
939987 [36854] that can't be the key of the chest of drawers... then there must be some
939987 [36855] other chest or strong-box... that's worth knowing. Strong-boxes always
939987 [36856] have keys like that... but how degrading it all is."
939987 [36857] 
939987 [36858] The old woman came back.
939987 [36859] 
939987 [36860] "Here, sir: as we say ten copecks the rouble a month, so I must take
939987 [36861] fifteen copecks from a rouble and a half for the month in advance. But
939987 [36862] for the two roubles I lent you before, you owe me now twenty copecks
939987 [36863] on the same reckoning in advance. That makes thirty-five copecks
939987 [36864] altogether. So I must give you a rouble and fifteen copecks for the
939987 [36865] watch. Here it is."
939987 [36866] 
939987 [36867] "What! only a rouble and fifteen copecks now!"
939987 [36868] 
939987 [36869] "Just so."
939987 [36870] 
939987 [36871] The young man did not dispute it and took the money. He looked at the
939987 [36872] old woman, and was in no hurry to get away, as though there was still
939987 [36873] something he wanted to say or to do, but he did not himself quite know
939987 [36874] what.
939987 [36875] 
939987 [36876] "I may be bringing you something else in a day or two, Alyona
939987 [36877] Ivanovna--a valuable thing--silver--a cigarette-box, as soon as I get it
939987 [36878] back from a friend..." he broke off in confusion.
939987 [36879] 
939987 [36880] "Well, we will talk about it then, sir."
939987 [36881] 
939987 [36882] "Good-bye--are you always at home alone, your sister is not here with
939987 [36883] you?" He asked her as casually as possible as he went out into the
939987 [36884] passage.
939987 [36885] 
939987 [36886] "What business is she of yours, my good sir?"
939987 [36887] 
939987 [36888] "Oh, nothing particular, I simply asked. You are too quick.... Good-day,
939987 [36889] Alyona Ivanovna."
939987 [36890] 
939987 [36891] Raskolnikov went out in complete confusion. This confusion became more
939987 [36892] and more intense. As he went down the stairs, he even stopped short, two
939987 [36893] or three times, as though suddenly struck by some thought. When he was

939987 [36895] can I, can I possibly.... No, it's nonsense, it's rubbish!" he added
939987 [36896] resolutely. "And how could such an atrocious thing come into my head?
939987 [36897] What filthy things my heart is capable of. Yes, filthy above all,
939987 [36898] disgusting, loathsome, loathsome!--and for a whole month I've been...."
939987 [36899] But no words, no exclamations, could express his agitation. The feeling
939987 [36900] of intense repulsion, which had begun to oppress and torture his heart
939987 [36901] while he was on his way to the old woman, had by now reached such a

939987 [36903] do with himself to escape from his wretchedness. He walked along the
939987 [36904] pavement like a drunken man, regardless of the passers-by, and jostling
939987 [36905] against them, and only came to his senses when he was in the next
939987 [36906] street. Looking round, he noticed that he was standing close to a tavern
939987 [36907] which was entered by steps leading from the pavement to the basement.
939987 [36908] At that instant two drunken men came out at the door, and abusing and
939987 [36909] supporting one another, they mounted the steps. Without stopping to
939987 [36910] think, Raskolnikov went down the steps at once. Till that moment he had
939987 [36911] never been into a tavern, but now he felt giddy and was tormented by a
939987 [36912] burning thirst. He longed for a drink of cold beer, and attributed his
939987 [36913] sudden weakness to the want of food. He sat down at a sticky little
939987 [36914] table in a dark and dirty corner; ordered some beer, and eagerly drank
939987 [36915] off the first glassful. At once he felt easier; and his thoughts became
939987 [36916] clear.
939987 [36917] 
939987 [36918] "All that's nonsense," he said hopefully, "and there is nothing in it
939987 [36919] all to worry about! It's simply physical derangement. Just a glass of
939987 [36920] beer, a piece of dry bread--and in one moment the brain is stronger,
939987 [36921] the mind is clearer and the will is firm! Phew, how utterly petty it all
939987 [36922] is!"
939987 [36923] 
939987 [36924] But in spite of this scornful reflection, he was by now looking cheerful
939987 [36925] as though he were suddenly set free from a terrible burden: and he gazed
939987 [36926] round in a friendly way at the people in the room. But even at that
939987 [36927] moment he had a dim foreboding that this happier frame of mind was also
939987 [36928] not normal.
939987 [36929] 
939987 [36930] There were few people at the time in the tavern. Besides the two drunken
939987 [36931] men he had met on the steps, a group consisting of about five men and
939987 [36932] a girl with a concertina had gone out at the same time. Their departure
939987 [36933] left the room quiet and rather empty. The persons still in the tavern
939987 [36934] were a man who appeared to be an artisan, drunk, but not extremely so,
939987 [36935] sitting before a pot of beer, and his companion, a huge, stout man with
939987 [36936] a grey beard, in a short full-skirted coat. He was very drunk: and had
939987 [36937] dropped asleep on the bench; every now and then, he began as though in
939987 [36938] his sleep, cracking his fingers, with his arms wide apart and the upper
939987 [36939] part of his body bounding about on the bench, while he hummed some
939987 [36940] meaningless refrain, trying to recall some such lines as these:
939987 [36941] 
939987 [36942]    "His wife a year he fondly loved
939987 [36943]     His wife a--a year he--fondly loved."
939987 [36944] 
939987 [36945] Or suddenly waking up again:
939987 [36946] 
939987 [36947]    "Walking along the crowded row
939987 [36948]     He met the one he used to know."
939987 [36949] 
939987 [36950] But no one shared his enjoyment: his silent companion looked with
939987 [36951] positive hostility and mistrust at all these manifestations. There was
939987 [36952] another man in the room who looked somewhat like a retired government
939987 [36953] clerk. He was sitting apart, now and then sipping from his pot and
939987 [36954] looking round at the company. He, too, appeared to be in some agitation.
939987 [36955] 
939987 [36956] 
939987 [36957] 
939987 [36958] CHAPTER II
939987 [36959] 
939987 [36960] Raskolnikov was not used to crowds, and, as we said before, he avoided
939987 [36961] society of every sort, more especially of late. But now all at once he
939987 [36962] felt a desire to be with other people. Something new seemed to be taking
939987 [36963] place within him, and with it he felt a sort of thirst for company. He
939987 [36964] was so weary after a whole month of concentrated wretchedness and gloomy
939987 [36965] excitement that he longed to rest, if only for a moment, in some other
939987 [36966] world, whatever it might be; and, in spite of the filthiness of the
939987 [36967] surroundings, he was glad now to stay in the tavern.
939987 [36968] 
939987 [36969] The master of the establishment was in another room, but he frequently
939987 [36970] came down some steps into the main room, his jaunty, tarred boots with
939987 [36971] red turn-over tops coming into view each time before the rest of his
939987 [36972] person. He wore a full coat and a horribly greasy black satin waistcoat,
939987 [36973] with no cravat, and his whole face seemed smeared with oil like an
939987 [36974] iron lock. At the counter stood a boy of about fourteen, and there was
939987 [36975] another boy somewhat younger who handed whatever was wanted. On the
939987 [36976] counter lay some sliced cucumber, some pieces of dried black bread, and
939987 [36977] some fish, chopped up small, all smelling very bad. It was insufferably
939987 [36978] close, and so heavy with the fumes of spirits that five minutes in such
939987 [36979] an atmosphere might well make a man drunk.
939987 [36980] 
939987 [36981] There are chance meetings with strangers that interest us from the
939987 [36982] first moment, before a word is spoken. Such was the impression made on
939987 [36983] Raskolnikov by the person sitting a little distance from him, who looked
939987 [36984] like a retired clerk. The young man often recalled this impression
939987 [36985] afterwards, and even ascribed it to presentiment. He looked repeatedly
939987 [36986] at the clerk, partly no doubt because the latter was staring
939987 [36987] persistently at him, obviously anxious to enter into conversation. At
939987 [36988] the other persons in the room, including the tavern-keeper, the clerk
939987 [36989] looked as though he were used to their company, and weary of it, showing
939987 [36990] a shade of condescending contempt for them as persons of station and
939987 [36991] culture inferior to his own, with whom it would be useless for him to
939987 [36992] converse. He was a man over fifty, bald and grizzled, of medium height,
939987 [36993] and stoutly built. His face, bloated from continual drinking, was of
939987 [36994] a yellow, even greenish, tinge, with swollen eyelids out of which keen
939987 [36995] reddish eyes gleamed like little chinks. But there was something very
939987 [36996] strange in him; there was a light in his eyes as though of intense
939987 [36997] feeling--perhaps there were even thought and intelligence, but at the
939987 [36998] same time there was a gleam of something like madness. He was wearing an
939987 [36999] old and hopelessly ragged black dress coat, with all its buttons missing
939987 [37000] except one, and that one he had buttoned, evidently clinging to this
939987 [37001] last trace of respectability. A crumpled shirt front, covered with spots
939987 [37002] and stains, protruded from his canvas waistcoat. Like a clerk, he wore
939987 [37003] no beard, nor moustache, but had been so long unshaven that his chin
939987 [37004] looked like a stiff greyish brush. And there was something respectable
939987 [37005] and like an official about his manner too. But he was restless; he
939987 [37006] ruffled up his hair and from time to time let his head drop into his
939987 [37007] hands dejectedly resting his ragged elbows on the stained and sticky
939987 [37008] table. At last he looked straight at Raskolnikov, and said loudly and
939987 [37009] resolutely:
939987 [37010] 
939987 [37011] "May I venture, honoured sir, to engage you in polite conversation?
939987 [37012] Forasmuch as, though your exterior would not command respect, my
939987 [37013] experience admonishes me that you are a man of education and not
939987 [37014] accustomed to drinking. I have always respected education when in
939987 [37015] conjunction with genuine sentiments, and I am besides a titular
939987 [37016] counsellor in rank. Marmeladov--such is my name; titular counsellor. I
939987 [37017] make bold to inquire--have you been in the service?"
939987 [37018] 
939987 [37019] "No, I am studying," answered the young man, somewhat surprised at
939987 [37020] the grandiloquent style of the speaker and also at being so directly
939987 [37021] addressed. In spite of the momentary desire he had just been feeling for
939987 [37022] company of any sort, on being actually spoken to he felt immediately his
939987 [37023] habitual irritable and uneasy aversion for any stranger who approached
939987 [37024] or attempted to approach him.
939987 [37025] 
939987 [37026] "A student then, or formerly a student," cried the clerk. "Just what
939987 [37027] I thought! I'm a man of experience, immense experience, sir," and he
939987 [37028] tapped his forehead with his fingers in self-approval. "You've been a
939987 [37029] student or have attended some learned institution!... But allow me...."
939987 [37030] He got up, staggered, took up his jug and glass, and sat down beside
939987 [37031] the young man, facing him a little sideways. He was drunk, but spoke
939987 [37032] fluently and boldly, only occasionally losing the thread of his
939987 [37033] sentences and drawling his words. He pounced upon Raskolnikov as
939987 [37034] greedily as though he too had not spoken to a soul for a month.
939987 [37035] 
939987 [37036] "Honoured sir," he began almost with solemnity, "poverty is not a vice,
939987 [37037] that's a true saying. Yet I know too that drunkenness is not a virtue,
939987 [37038] and that that's even truer. But beggary, honoured sir, beggary is a
939987 [37039] vice. In poverty you may still retain your innate nobility of soul, but
939987 [37040] in beggary--never--no one. For beggary a man is not chased out of human
939987 [37041] society with a stick, he is swept out with a broom, so as to make it as
939987 [37042] humiliating as possible; and quite right, too, forasmuch as in beggary
939987 [37043] I am ready to be the first to humiliate myself. Hence the pot-house!
939987 [37044] Honoured sir, a month ago Mr. Lebeziatnikov gave my wife a beating, and
939987 [37045] my wife is a very different matter from me! Do you understand? Allow me
939987 [37046] to ask you another question out of simple curiosity: have you ever spent
939987 [37047] a night on a hay barge, on the Neva?"
939987 [37048] 
939987 [37049] "No, I have not happened to," answered Raskolnikov. "What do you mean?"
939987 [37050] 
939987 [37051] "Well, I've just come from one and it's the fifth night I've slept
939987 [37052] so...." He filled his glass, emptied it and paused. Bits of hay were in
939987 [37053] fact clinging to his clothes and sticking to his hair. It seemed quite
939987 [37054] probable that he had not undressed or washed for the last five days.
939987 [37055] His hands, particularly, were filthy. They were fat and red, with black
939987 [37056] nails.
939987 [37057] 
939987 [37058] His conversation seemed to excite a general though languid interest. The
939987 [37059] boys at the counter fell to sniggering. The innkeeper came down from the
939987 [37060] upper room, apparently on purpose to listen to the "funny fellow"
939987 [37061] and sat down at a little distance, yawning lazily, but with dignity.
939987 [37062] Evidently Marmeladov was a familiar figure here, and he had most
939987 [37063] likely acquired his weakness for high-flown speeches from the habit of
939987 [37064] frequently entering into conversation with strangers of all sorts in
939987 [37065] the tavern. This habit develops into a necessity in some drunkards, and
939987 [37066] especially in those who are looked after sharply and kept in order
939987 [37067] at home. Hence in the company of other drinkers they try to justify
939987 [37068] themselves and even if possible obtain consideration.
939987 [37069] 
939987 [37070] "Funny fellow!" pronounced the innkeeper. "And why don't you work, why
939987 [37071] aren't you at your duty, if you are in the service?"
939987 [37072] 
939987 [37073] "Why am I not at my duty, honoured sir," Marmeladov went on, addressing
939987 [37074] himself exclusively to Raskolnikov, as though it had been he who put
939987 [37075] that question to him. "Why am I not at my duty? Does not my heart ache
939987 [37076] to think what a useless worm I am? A month ago when Mr. Lebeziatnikov
939987 [37077] beat my wife with his own hands, and I lay drunk, didn't I suffer?
939987 [37078] Excuse me, young man, has it ever happened to you... hm... well, to
939987 [37079] petition hopelessly for a loan?"
939987 [37080] 
939987 [37081] "Yes, it has. But what do you mean by hopelessly?"
939987 [37082] 
939987 [37083] "Hopelessly in the fullest sense, when you know beforehand that you
939987 [37084] will get nothing by it. You know, for instance, beforehand with positive
939987 [37085] certainty that this man, this most reputable and exemplary citizen, will
939987 [37086] on no consideration give you money; and indeed I ask you why should he?
939987 [37087] For he knows of course that I shan't pay it back. From compassion? But
939987 [37088] Mr. Lebeziatnikov who keeps up with modern ideas explained the other day
939987 [37089] that compassion is forbidden nowadays by science itself, and that that's
939987 [37090] what is done now in England, where there is political economy. Why, I
939987 [37091] ask you, should he give it to me? And yet though I know beforehand that
939987 [37092] he won't, I set off to him and..."
939987 [37093] 
939987 [37094] "Why do you go?" put in Raskolnikov.
939987 [37095] 
939987 [37096] "Well, when one has no one, nowhere else one can go! For every man must
939987 [37097] have somewhere to go. Since there are times when one absolutely must
939987 [37098] go somewhere! When my own daughter first went out with a yellow ticket,
939987 [37099] then I had to go... (for my daughter has a yellow passport)," he added
939987 [37100] in parenthesis, looking with a certain uneasiness at the young man.

939987 [37103] innkeeper smiled--"No matter, I am not confounded by the wagging of
939987 [37104] their heads; for everyone knows everything about it already, and all
939987 [37105] that is secret is made open. And I accept it all, not with contempt, but
939987 [37106] with humility. So be it! So be it! 'Behold the man!' Excuse me, young
939987 [37107] man, can you.... No, to put it more strongly and more distinctly; not
939987 [37108] _can_ you but _dare_ you, looking upon me, assert that I am not a pig?"
939987 [37109] 
939987 [37110] The young man did not answer a word.
939987 [37111] 
939987 [37112] "Well," the orator began again stolidly and with even increased dignity,
939987 [37113] after waiting for the laughter in the room to subside. "Well, so be
939987 [37114] it, I am a pig, but she is a lady! I have the semblance of a beast, but
939987 [37115] Katerina Ivanovna, my spouse, is a person of education and an officer's
939987 [37116] daughter. Granted, granted, I am a scoundrel, but she is a woman of a
939987 [37117] noble heart, full of sentiments, refined by education. And yet... oh,
939987 [37118] if only she felt for me! Honoured sir, honoured sir, you know every man
939987 [37119] ought to have at least one place where people feel for him! But Katerina
939987 [37120] Ivanovna, though she is magnanimous, she is unjust.... And yet, although
939987 [37121] I realise that when she pulls my hair she only does it out of pity--for
939987 [37122] I repeat without being ashamed, she pulls my hair, young man," he
939987 [37123] declared with redoubled dignity, hearing the sniggering again--"but, my
939987 [37124] God, if she would but once.... But no, no! It's all in vain and it's no
939987 [37125] use talking! No use talking! For more than once, my wish did come true
939987 [37126] and more than once she has felt for me but... such is my fate and I am a
939987 [37127] beast by nature!"
939987 [37128] 
939987 [37129] "Rather!" assented the innkeeper yawning. Marmeladov struck his fist
939987 [37130] resolutely on the table.
939987 [37131] 
939987 [37132] "Such is my fate! Do you know, sir, do you know, I have sold her very
939987 [37133] stockings for drink? Not her shoes--that would be more or less in the
939987 [37134] order of things, but her stockings, her stockings I have sold for drink!
939987 [37135] Her mohair shawl I sold for drink, a present to her long ago, her own
939987 [37136] property, not mine; and we live in a cold room and she caught cold this
939987 [37137] winter and has begun coughing and spitting blood too. We have three
939987 [37138] little children and Katerina Ivanovna is at work from morning till
939987 [37139] night; she is scrubbing and cleaning and washing the children, for she's
939987 [37140] been used to cleanliness from a child. But her chest is weak and she has
939987 [37141] a tendency to consumption and I feel it! Do you suppose I don't feel it?
939987 [37142] And the more I drink the more I feel it. That's why I drink too. I try
939987 [37143] to find sympathy and feeling in drink.... I drink so that I may suffer
939987 [37144] twice as much!" And as though in despair he laid his head down on the

939987 [37477] she does begin pulling it, that's not what I am afraid of... it's her
939987 [37478] eyes I am afraid of... yes, her eyes... the red on her cheeks, too,
939987 [37479] frightens me... and her breathing too.... Have you noticed how people
939987 [37480] in that disease breathe... when they are excited? I am frightened of
939987 [37481] the children's crying, too.... For if Sonia has not taken them food...
939987 [37482] I don't know what's happened! I don't know! But blows I am not afraid
939987 [37483] of.... Know, sir, that such blows are not a pain to me, but even an
939987 [37484] enjoyment. In fact I can't get on without it.... It's better so. Let
939987 [37485] her strike me, it relieves her heart... it's better so... There is the
939987 [37486] house. The house of Kozel, the cabinet-maker... a German, well-to-do.
939987 [37487] Lead the way!"
939987 [37488] 
939987 [37489] They went in from the yard and up to the fourth storey. The staircase
939987 [37490] got darker and darker as they went up. It was nearly eleven o'clock
939987 [37491] and although in summer in Petersburg there is no real night, yet it was
939987 [37492] quite dark at the top of the stairs.
939987 [37493] 
939987 [37494] A grimy little door at the very top of the stairs stood ajar. A very
939987 [37495] poor-looking room about ten paces long was lighted up by a candle-end;
939987 [37496] the whole of it was visible from the entrance. It was all in disorder,
939987 [37497] littered up with rags of all sorts, especially children's garments.
939987 [37498] Across the furthest corner was stretched a ragged sheet. Behind it
939987 [37499] probably was the bed. There was nothing in the room except two chairs
939987 [37500] and a sofa covered with American leather, full of holes, before which

939987 [37504] but their room was practically a passage. The door leading to the other

939987 [37508] of the most unceremonious kind flew out from time to time.
939987 [37509] 
939987 [37510] Raskolnikov recognised Katerina Ivanovna at once. She was a rather tall,

939987 [37519] Marmeladov.... She had not heard them and did not notice them coming in.
939987 [37520] She seemed to be lost in thought, hearing and seeing nothing. The room
939987 [37521] was close, but she had not opened the window; a stench rose from the
939987 [37522] staircase, but the door on to the stairs was not closed. From the inner
939987 [37523] rooms clouds of tobacco smoke floated in, she kept coughing, but did not
939987 [37524] close the door. The youngest child, a girl of six, was asleep, sitting
939987 [37525] curled up on the floor with her head on the sofa. A boy a year older
939987 [37526] stood crying and shaking in the corner, probably he had just had a
939987 [37527] beating. Beside him stood a girl of nine years old, tall and thin,
939987 [37528] wearing a thin and ragged chemise with an ancient cashmere pelisse flung
939987 [37529] over her bare shoulders, long outgrown and barely reaching her knees.
939987 [37530] Her arm, as thin as a stick, was round her brother's neck. She was
939987 [37531] trying to comfort him, whispering something to him, and doing all she

939987 [37541] and uttered a sudden scream on seeing her husband on his knees in the
939987 [37542] doorway.
939987 [37543] 
939987 [37544] "Ah!" she cried out in a frenzy, "he has come back! The criminal! the
939987 [37545] monster!... And where is the money? What's in your pocket, show me! And
939987 [37546] your clothes are all different! Where are your clothes? Where is the
939987 [37547] money! Speak!"
939987 [37548] 
939987 [37549] And she fell to searching him. Marmeladov submissively and obediently
939987 [37550] held up both arms to facilitate the search. Not a farthing was there.
939987 [37551] 
939987 [37552] "Where is the money?" she cried--"Mercy on us, can he have drunk it all?
939987 [37553] There were twelve silver roubles left in the chest!" and in a fury

939987 [37555] seconded her efforts by meekly crawling along on his knees.
939987 [37556] 
939987 [37557] "And this is a consolation to me! This does not hurt me, but is a
939987 [37558] positive con-so-la-tion, ho-nou-red sir," he called out, shaken to and
939987 [37559] fro by his hair and even once striking the ground with his forehead.
939987 [37560] The child asleep on the floor woke up, and began to cry. The boy in the
939987 [37561] corner losing all control began trembling and screaming and rushed
939987 [37562] to his sister in violent terror, almost in a fit. The eldest girl was
939987 [37563] shaking like a leaf.
939987 [37564] 
939987 [37565] "He's drunk it! he's drunk it all," the poor woman screamed in
939987 [37566] despair--"and his clothes are gone! And they are hungry, hungry!"--and

939987 [37568] And you, are you not ashamed?"--she pounced all at once upon
939987 [37569] Raskolnikov--"from the tavern! Have you been drinking with him? You have
939987 [37570] been drinking with him, too! Go away!"
939987 [37571] 
939987 [37572] The young man was hastening away without uttering a word. The inner door
939987 [37573] was thrown wide open and inquisitive faces were peering in at it. Coarse
939987 [37574] laughing faces with pipes and cigarettes and heads wearing caps thrust

939987 [37578] Marmeladov, dragged about by his hair, shouted that it was a consolation

939987 [37582] for the hundredth time to frighten the poor woman by ordering her

939987 [37585] coppers he had received in exchange for his rouble in the tavern and to

939987 [37587] his mind and would have gone back.
939987 [37588] 
939987 [37589] "What a stupid thing I've done," he thought to himself, "they have Sonia
939987 [37590] and I want it myself." But reflecting that it would be impossible to
939987 [37591] take it back now and that in any case he would not have taken it, he
939987 [37592] dismissed it with a wave of his hand and went back to his lodging.
939987 [37593] "Sonia wants pomatum too," he said as he walked along the street, and he
939987 [37594] laughed malignantly--"such smartness costs money.... Hm! And maybe Sonia
939987 [37595] herself will be bankrupt to-day, for there is always a risk, hunting
939987 [37596] big game... digging for gold... then they would all be without a crust

939987 [37598] there! And they're making the most of it! Yes, they are making the most
939987 [37599] of it! They've wept over it and grown used to it. Man grows used to
939987 [37600] everything, the scoundrel!"
939987 [37601] 
939987 [37602] He sank into thought.
939987 [37603] 
939987 [37604] "And what if I am wrong," he cried suddenly after a moment's thought.
939987 [37605] "What if man is not really a scoundrel, man in general, I mean, the
939987 [37606] whole race of mankind--then all the rest is prejudice, simply artificial
939987 [37607] terrors and there are no barriers and it's all as it should be."
939987 [37608] 
939987 [37609] 
939987 [37610] 
939987 [37611] CHAPTER III
939987 [37612] 
939987 [37613] He waked up late next day after a broken sleep. But his sleep had not
939987 [37614] refreshed him; he waked up bilious, irritable, ill-tempered, and looked
939987 [37615] with hatred at his room. It was a tiny cupboard of a room about six
939987 [37616] paces in length. It had a poverty-stricken appearance with its dusty
939987 [37617] yellow paper peeling off the walls, and it was so low-pitched that a man
939987 [37618] of more than average height was ill at ease in it and felt every moment
939987 [37619] that he would knock his head against the ceiling. The furniture was in
939987 [37620] keeping with the room: there were three old chairs, rather rickety; a
939987 [37621] painted table in the corner on which lay a few manuscripts and books;
939987 [37622] the dust that lay thick upon them showed that they had been long
939987 [37623] untouched. A big clumsy sofa occupied almost the whole of one wall and
939987 [37624] half the floor space of the room; it was once covered with chintz, but
939987 [37625] was now in rags and served Raskolnikov as a bed. Often he went to sleep
939987 [37626] on it, as he was, without undressing, without sheets, wrapped in his old
939987 [37627] student's overcoat, with his head on one little pillow, under which he
939987 [37628] heaped up all the linen he had, clean and dirty, by way of a bolster. A
939987 [37629] little table stood in front of the sofa.
939987 [37630] 
939987 [37631] It would have been difficult to sink to a lower ebb of disorder, but to
939987 [37632] Raskolnikov in his present state of mind this was positively agreeable.
939987 [37633] He had got completely away from everyone, like a tortoise in its shell,
939987 [37634] and even the sight of a servant girl who had to wait upon him and looked
939987 [37635] sometimes into his room made him writhe with nervous irritation. He was
939987 [37636] in the condition that overtakes some monomaniacs entirely concentrated
939987 [37637] upon one thing. His landlady had for the last fortnight given up sending
939987 [37638] him in meals, and he had not yet thought of expostulating with her,
939987 [37639] though he went without his dinner. Nastasya, the cook and only servant,
939987 [37640] was rather pleased at the lodger's mood and had entirely given up
939987 [37641] sweeping and doing his room, only once a week or so she would stray into
939987 [37642] his room with a broom. She waked him up that day.
939987 [37643] 
939987 [37644] "Get up, why are you asleep?" she called to him. "It's past nine, I have
939987 [37645] brought you some tea; will you have a cup? I should think you're fairly
939987 [37646] starving?"
939987 [37647] 
939987 [37648] Raskolnikov opened his eyes, started and recognised Nastasya.
939987 [37649] 
939987 [37650] "From the landlady, eh?" he asked, slowly and with a sickly face sitting
939987 [37651] up on the sofa.
939987 [37652] 
939987 [37653] "From the landlady, indeed!"
939987 [37654] 
939987 [37655] She set before him her own cracked teapot full of weak and stale tea and
939987 [37656] laid two yellow lumps of sugar by the side of it.
939987 [37657] 
939987 [37658] "Here, Nastasya, take it please," he said, fumbling in his pocket (for
939987 [37659] he had slept in his clothes) and taking out a handful of coppers--"run
939987 [37660] and buy me a loaf. And get me a little sausage, the cheapest, at the
939987 [37661] pork-butcher's."
939987 [37662] 
939987 [37663] "The loaf I'll fetch you this very minute, but wouldn't you rather have
939987 [37664] some cabbage soup instead of sausage? It's capital soup, yesterday's. I
939987 [37665] saved it for you yesterday, but you came in late. It's fine soup."
939987 [37666] 
939987 [37667] When the soup had been brought, and he had begun upon it, Nastasya
939987 [37668] sat down beside him on the sofa and began chatting. She was a country
939987 [37669] peasant-woman and a very talkative one.
939987 [37670] 
939987 [37671] "Praskovya Pavlovna means to complain to the police about you," she
939987 [37672] said.
939987 [37673] 
939987 [37674] He scowled.
939987 [37675] 
939987 [37676] "To the police? What does she want?"
939987 [37677] 
939987 [37678] "You don't pay her money and you won't turn out of the room. That's what
939987 [37679] she wants, to be sure."
939987 [37680] 
939987 [37681] "The devil, that's the last straw," he muttered, grinding his teeth,
939987 [37682] "no, that would not suit me... just now. She is a fool," he added aloud.
939987 [37683] "I'll go and talk to her to-day."
939987 [37684] 
939987 [37685] "Fool she is and no mistake, just as I am. But why, if you are so

939987 [37688] do nothing now?"
939987 [37689] 
939987 [37690] "I am doing..." Raskolnikov began sullenly and reluctantly.
939987 [37691] 
939987 [37692] "What are you doing?"

939987 [37695] 
939987 [37696] "What sort of work?"
939987 [37697]

939987 [37699] 
939987 [37700] Nastasya was overcome with a fit of laughter. She was given to laughter
939987 [37701] and when anything amused her, she laughed inaudibly, quivering and

939987 [37703] 
939987 [37704] "And have you made much money by your thinking?" she managed to

939987 [37706]

939987 [37708]

939987 [37710] 
939987 [37711] "They pay so little for lessons. What's the use of a few coppers?" he
939987 [37712] answered, reluctantly, as though replying to his own thought.
939987 [37713] 
939987 [37714] "And you want to get a fortune all at once?"
939987 [37715] 
939987 [37716] He looked at her strangely.
939987 [37717]

939987 [37719] 
939987 [37720] "Don't be in such a hurry, you quite frighten me! Shall I get you the

939987 [37734]

939987 [37739]

939987 [37743] The letter was quivering in his hand; he did not want to open it in her

939987 [37752] "My dear Rodya," wrote his mother--"it's two months since I last had a

939987 [37798] especially when Mr. SvidrigaÃ¯lov, relapsing into his old regimental
939987 [37799] habits, was under the influence of Bacchus. And how do you think it
939987 [37800] was all explained later on? Would you believe that the crazy fellow had
939987 [37801] conceived a passion for Dounia from the beginning, but had concealed
939987 [37802] it under a show of rudeness and contempt. Possibly he was ashamed and

939987 [37810] through! To leave her situation at once was impossible not only on

939987 [37812] Petrovna, whose suspicions would have been aroused: and then Dounia

939987 [37842] us. All our acquaintances avoided us, nobody even bowed to us in the
939987 [37843] street, and I learnt that some shopmen and clerks were intending to
939987 [37844] insult us in a shameful way, smearing the gates of our house with pitch,
939987 [37845] so that the landlord began to tell us we must leave. All this was set
939987 [37846] going by Marfa Petrovna who managed to slander Dounia and throw dirt at
939987 [37847] her in every family. She knows everyone in the neighbourhood, and that
939987 [37848] month she was continually coming into the town, and as she is
939987 [37849] rather talkative and fond of gossiping about her family affairs and
939987 [37850] particularly of complaining to all and each of her husband--which is not
939987 [37851] at all right--so in a short time she had spread her story not only in
939987 [37852] the town, but over the whole surrounding district. It made me ill, but
939987 [37853] Dounia bore it better than I did, and if only you could have seen how
939987 [37854] she endured it all and tried to comfort me and cheer me up! She is
939987 [37855] an angel! But by God's mercy, our sufferings were cut short: Mr.
939987 [37856] SvidrigaÃ¯lov returned to his senses and repented and, probably
939987 [37857] feeling sorry for Dounia, he laid before Marfa Petrovna a complete and
939987 [37858] unmistakable proof of Dounia's innocence, in the form of a letter Dounia
939987 [37859] had been forced to write and give to him, before Marfa Petrovna
939987 [37860] came upon them in the garden. This letter, which remained in Mr.
939987 [37861] SvidrigaÃ¯lov's hands after her departure, she had written to refuse
939987 [37862] personal explanations and secret interviews, for which he was entreating
939987 [37863] her. In that letter she reproached him with great heat and indignation
939987 [37864] for the baseness of his behaviour in regard to Marfa Petrovna, reminding

939987 [37869] read it without tears. Moreover, the evidence of the servants, too,
939987 [37870] cleared Dounia's reputation; they had seen and known a great deal more
939987 [37871] than Mr. SvidrigaÃ¯lov had himself supposed--as indeed is always the case

939987 [37874] Dounia's innocence. The very next day, being Sunday, she went straight

939987 [37886] the whole town, because some people had taken offence through precedence

939987 [37888] that in every house she was expected before she arrived, and everyone

939987 [37909] Petrovitch Luzhin, and is distantly related to Marfa Petrovna, who
939987 [37910] has been very active in bringing the match about. It began with his

939987 [37972] the ikon and prayed long and fervently and in the morning she told me

939987 [37974] 
939987 [37975] "I have mentioned already that Pyotr Petrovitch is just setting off for
939987 [37976] Petersburg, where he has a great deal of business, and he wants to open
939987 [37977] a legal bureau. He has been occupied for many years in conducting civil

939987 [38085] 
939987 [38086] 
939987 [38087] Almost from the first, while he read the letter, Raskolnikov's face was
939987 [38088] wet with tears; but when he finished it, his face was pale and distorted
939987 [38089] and a bitter, wrathful and malignant smile was on his lips. He laid his
939987 [38090] head down on his threadbare dirty pillow and pondered, pondered a long
939987 [38091] time. His heart was beating violently, and his brain was in a turmoil.
939987 [38092] At last he felt cramped and stifled in the little yellow room that was
939987 [38093] like a cupboard or a box. His eyes and his mind craved for space. He
939987 [38094] took up his hat and went out, this time without dread of meeting
939987 [38095] anyone; he had forgotten his dread. He turned in the direction of the
939987 [38096] Vassilyevsky Ostrov, walking along Vassilyevsky Prospect, as though
939987 [38097] hastening on some business, but he walked, as his habit was, without
939987 [38098] noticing his way, muttering and even speaking aloud to himself, to the
939987 [38099] astonishment of the passers-by. Many of them took him to be drunk.
939987 [38100] 
939987 [38101] 
939987 [38102] 
939987 [38103] CHAPTER IV
939987 [38104] 
939987 [38105] His mother's letter had been a torture to him, but as regards the chief
939987 [38106] fact in it, he had felt not one moment's hesitation, even whilst he was
939987 [38107] reading the letter. The essential question was settled, and irrevocably
939987 [38108] settled, in his mind: "Never such a marriage while I am alive and
939987 [38109] Mr. Luzhin be damned!" "The thing is perfectly clear," he muttered
939987 [38110] to himself, with a malignant smile anticipating the triumph of his
939987 [38111] decision. "No, mother, no, Dounia, you won't deceive me! and then they
939987 [38112] apologise for not asking my advice and for taking the decision without
939987 [38113] me! I dare say! They imagine it is arranged now and can't be broken
939987 [38114] off; but we will see whether it can or not! A magnificent excuse:
939987 [38115] 'Pyotr Petrovitch is such a busy man that even his wedding has to be in
939987 [38116] post-haste, almost by express.' No, Dounia, I see it all and I know what
939987 [38117] you want to say to me; and I know too what you were thinking about, when
939987 [38118] you walked up and down all night, and what your prayers were like before
939987 [38119] the Holy Mother of Kazan who stands in mother's bedroom. Bitter is
939987 [38120] the ascent to Golgotha.... Hm... so it is finally settled; you have
939987 [38121] determined to marry a sensible business man, Avdotya Romanovna, one
939987 [38122] who has a fortune (has _already_ made his fortune, that is so much
939987 [38123] more solid and impressive) a man who holds two government posts and who
939987 [38124] shares the ideas of our most rising generation, as mother writes, and
939987 [38125] who _seems_ to be kind, as Dounia herself observes. That _seems_ beats
939987 [38126] everything! And that very Dounia for that very '_seems_' is marrying
939987 [38127] him! Splendid! splendid!
939987 [38128] 
939987 [38129] "... But I should like to know why mother has written to me about 'our
939987 [38130] most rising generation'? Simply as a descriptive touch, or with the idea
939987 [38131] of prepossessing me in favour of Mr. Luzhin? Oh, the cunning of them!
939987 [38132] I should like to know one thing more: how far they were open with one
939987 [38133] another that day and night and all this time since? Was it all put into
939987 [38134] _words_, or did both understand that they had the same thing at heart
939987 [38135] and in their minds, so that there was no need to speak of it aloud, and
939987 [38136] better not to speak of it. Most likely it was partly like that, from
939987 [38137] mother's letter it's evident: he struck her as rude _a little_, and
939987 [38138] mother in her simplicity took her observations to Dounia. And she was
939987 [38139] sure to be vexed and 'answered her angrily.' I should think so! Who
939987 [38140] would not be angered when it was quite clear without any naÃ¯ve questions
939987 [38141] and when it was understood that it was useless to discuss it. And why
939987 [38142] does she write to me, 'love Dounia, Rodya, and she loves you more than
939987 [38143] herself'? Has she a secret conscience-prick at sacrificing her daughter
939987 [38144] to her son? 'You are our one comfort, you are everything to us.' Oh,
939987 [38145] mother!"
939987 [38146] 
939987 [38147] His bitterness grew more and more intense, and if he had happened to
939987 [38148] meet Mr. Luzhin at the moment, he might have murdered him.
939987 [38149] 
939987 [38150] "Hm... yes, that's true," he continued, pursuing the whirling ideas that
939987 [38151] chased each other in his brain, "it is true that 'it needs time and care
939987 [38152] to get to know a man,' but there is no mistake about Mr. Luzhin. The
939987 [38153] chief thing is he is 'a man of business and _seems_ kind,' that was
939987 [38154] something, wasn't it, to send the bags and big box for them! A kind man,
939987 [38155] no doubt after that! But his _bride_ and her mother are to drive in a
939987 [38156] peasant's cart covered with sacking (I know, I have been driven in
939987 [38157] it). No matter! It is only ninety versts and then they can 'travel very
939987 [38158] comfortably, third class,' for a thousand versts! Quite right, too. One
939987 [38159] must cut one's coat according to one's cloth, but what about you, Mr.
939987 [38160] Luzhin? She is your bride.... And you must be aware that her mother has
939987 [38161] to raise money on her pension for the journey. To be sure it's a matter
939987 [38162] of business, a partnership for mutual benefit, with equal shares and
939987 [38163] expenses;--food and drink provided, but pay for your tobacco. The
939987 [38164] business man has got the better of them, too. The luggage will cost less
939987 [38165] than their fares and very likely go for nothing. How is it that they
939987 [38166] don't both see all that, or is it that they don't want to see? And
939987 [38167] they are pleased, pleased! And to think that this is only the first
939987 [38168] blossoming, and that the real fruits are to come! But what really
939987 [38169] matters is not the stinginess, is not the meanness, but the _tone_
939987 [38170] of the whole thing. For that will be the tone after marriage, it's a
939987 [38171] foretaste of it. And mother too, why should she be so lavish? What will
939987 [38172] she have by the time she gets to Petersburg? Three silver roubles or

939987 [38534] He wondered at himself. Razumihin was one of his old comrades at the

939987 [38562] could lodge anywhere, and bear the extremes of cold and hunger. He was
939987 [38563] very poor, and kept himself entirely on what he could earn by work of

939987 [38565] money. He spent one whole winter without lighting his stove, and used to
