939987 [38648] In a morbid condition of the brain, dreams often have a singular

939987 [38907] He rose to his feet, looked round in wonder as though surprised at

939987 [39006] 
939987 [39007] Certainly, if he had to wait whole years for a suitable opportunity, he

939987 [39290] him beforehand under the sofa. He had only just got the pledge out when
939987 [39291] he heard someone suddenly about in the yard.
939987 [39292] 
939987 [39293] "It struck six long ago."
939987 [39294] 
939987 [39295] "Long ago! My God!"
939987 [39296] 
939987 [39297] He rushed to the door, listened, caught up his hat and began to descend

939987 [39309] 
939987 [39310] And, indeed, if it had ever happened that everything to the least point

939987 [39327] 
939987 [39328] But those were all trifles which he had not even begun to consider, and

939987 [39338] Meanwhile it would seem, as regards the moral question, that his

939987 [39342] arguments in all directions, fumbling for them, as though someone were
939987 [39343] forcing and drawing him to it.
939987 [39344] 
939987 [39345] At first--long before indeed--he had been much occupied with one
939987 [39346] question; why almost all crimes are so badly concealed and so easily
939987 [39347] detected, and why almost all criminals leave such obvious traces? He
939987 [39348] had come gradually to many different and curious conclusions, and in his
939987 [39349] opinion the chief reason lay not so much in the material impossibility
939987 [39350] of concealing the crime, as in the criminal himself. Almost every
939987 [39351] criminal is subject to a failure of will and reasoning power by a
939987 [39352] childish and phenomenal heedlessness, at the very instant when prudence
939987 [39353] and caution are most essential. It was his conviction that this eclipse
939987 [39354] of reason and failure of will power attacked a man like a disease,
939987 [39355] developed gradually and reached its highest point just before the
939987 [39356] perpetration of the crime, continued with equal violence at the moment
939987 [39357] of the crime and for longer or shorter time after, according to the
939987 [39358] individual case, and then passed off like any other disease. The
939987 [39359] question whether the disease gives rise to the crime, or whether the

939987 [39361] the nature of disease, he did not yet feel able to decide.
939987 [39362] 
939987 [39363] When he reached these conclusions, he decided that in his own case there

939987 [39374] came to trust least, and when the hour struck, it all came to pass quite

939987 [39376] 
939987 [39377] One trifling circumstance upset his calculations, before he had even

939987 [39389] 
939987 [39390] "What made me think," he reflected, as he went under the gateway, "what

939987 [39420] Glancing out of the corner of his eye into a shop, he saw by a clock on

939987 [39460]

939987 [39506] CHAPTER VII
939987 [39507] 
939987 [39508] The door was as before opened a tiny crack, and again two sharp and

939987 [39510] his head and nearly made a great mistake.
939987 [39511] 
939987 [39512] Fearing the old woman would be frightened by their being alone, and not

939987 [39525] 
939987 [39526] And leaving her, he passed straight into the room uninvited. The old

939987 [40817] though he felt shattered, he had his senses about him. He was afraid of
939987 [40818] pursuit, he was afraid that in another half-hour, another quarter of an
939987 [40819] hour perhaps, instructions would be issued for his pursuit, and so at
939987 [40820] all costs, he must hide all traces before then. He must clear everything
939987 [40821] up while he still had some strength, some reasoning power left him....
939987 [40822] Where was he to go?
939987 [40823] 
939987 [40824] That had long been settled: "Fling them into the canal, and all traces
939987 [40825] hidden in the water, the thing would be at an end." So he had decided in
939987 [40826] the night of his delirium when several times he had had the impulse to
939987 [40827] get up and go away, to make haste, and get rid of it all. But to get
939987 [40828] rid of it, turned out to be a very difficult task. He wandered along
939987 [40829] the bank of the Ekaterininsky Canal for half an hour or more and looked
939987 [40830] several times at the steps running down to the water, but he could not
939987 [40831] think of carrying out his plan; either rafts stood at the steps' edge,
939987 [40832] and women were washing clothes on them, or boats were moored there, and
939987 [40833] people were swarming everywhere. Moreover he could be seen and noticed
939987 [40834] from the banks on all sides; it would look suspicious for a man to go
939987 [40835] down on purpose, stop, and throw something into the water. And what if
939987 [40836] the boxes were to float instead of sinking? And of course they would.
939987 [40837] Even as it was, everyone he met seemed to stare and look round, as if

939987 [40839] fancy?" he thought.

939987 [41231] He was not completely unconscious, however, all the time he was ill; he
939987 [41232] was in a feverish state, sometimes delirious, sometimes half conscious.
939987 [41233] He remembered a great deal afterwards. Sometimes it seemed as though
939987 [41234] there were a number of people round him; they wanted to take him away
939987 [41235] somewhere, there was a great deal of squabbling and discussing about
939987 [41236] him. Then he would be alone in the room; they had all gone away afraid
939987 [41237] of him, and only now and then opened the door a crack to look at him;
939987 [41238] they threatened him, plotted something together, laughed, and mocked
939987 [41239] at him. He remembered Nastasya often at his bedside; he distinguished
939987 [41240] another person, too, whom he seemed to know very well, though he could
939987 [41241] not remember who he was, and this fretted him, even made him cry.
939987 [41242] Sometimes he fancied he had been lying there a month; at other times
939987 [41243] it all seemed part of the same day. But of _that_--of _that_ he had
939987 [41244] no recollection, and yet every minute he felt that he had forgotten
939987 [41245] something he ought to remember. He worried and tormented himself trying
939987 [41246] to remember, moaned, flew into a rage, or sank into awful, intolerable
939987 [41247] terror. Then he struggled to get up, would have run away, but someone
939987 [41248] always prevented him by force, and he sank back into impotence and
939987 [41249] forgetfulness. At last he returned to complete consciousness.
939987 [41250] 
939987 [41251] It happened at ten o'clock in the morning. On fine days the sun shone
939987 [41252] into the room at that hour, throwing a streak of light on the right
939987 [41253] wall and the corner near the door. Nastasya was standing beside him
939987 [41254] with another person, a complete stranger, who was looking at him
939987 [41255] very inquisitively. He was a young man with a beard, wearing a full,
939987 [41256] short-waisted coat, and looked like a messenger. The landlady was
939987 [41257] peeping in at the half-opened door. Raskolnikov sat up.

939987 [41268] and buxom, with black eyes and eyebrows, good-natured from fatness and
939987 [41269] laziness, and absurdly bashful.

939987 [43560] perfect pool there."

939987 [43680] CHAPTER VII
939987 [43681] 
939987 [43682] An elegant carriage stood in the middle of the road with a pair of

939987 [43689]

939987 [43698]

939987 [43706] tipsy.... The horses are young and ready to take fright... they started,
939987 [43707] he screamed... that made them worse. That's how it happened!"
939987 [43708]

939987 [43710] 
939987 [43711] "He shouted, that's true, he shouted three times," another voice
939987 [43712] declared.
939987 [43713] 
939987 [43714] "Three times it was, we all heard it," shouted a third.
939987 [43715]

939987 [43748] 
939987 [43749] Kozel's house was thirty yards away. Raskolnikov walked behind,

939987 [43754] 
939987 [43755] Katerina Ivanovna had just begun, as she always did at every free
939987 [43756] moment, walking to and fro in her little room from window to stove and
939987 [43757] back again, with her arms folded across her chest, talking to herself

939987 [43763] brother, who had been unwell all day and was going to bed. The boy was
939987 [43764] waiting for her to take off his shirt, which had to be washed at night.
939987 [43765] He was sitting straight and motionless on a chair, with a silent,

939987 [45010] CHAPTER II
939987 [45011] 
939987 [45012] Razumihin waked up next morning at eight o'clock, troubled and serious.
939987 [45013] He found himself confronted with many new and unlooked-for perplexities.
939987 [45014] He had never expected that he would ever wake up feeling like that. He
939987 [45015] remembered every detail of the previous day and he knew that a perfectly
939987 [45016] novel experience had befallen him, that he had received an impression
939987 [45017] unlike anything he had known before. At the same time he recognised
939987 [45018] clearly that the dream which had fired his imagination was hopelessly
939987 [45019] unattainable--so unattainable that he felt positively ashamed of it, and
939987 [45020] he hastened to pass to the other more practical cares and difficulties
939987 [45021] bequeathed him by that "thrice accursed yesterday."
939987 [45022] 
939987 [45023] The most awful recollection of the previous day was the way he had shown
939987 [45024] himself "base and mean," not only because he had been drunk, but
939987 [45025] because he had taken advantage of the young girl's position to abuse
939987 [45026] her _fiancÃ©_ in his stupid jealousy, knowing nothing of their mutual
939987 [45027] relations and obligations and next to nothing of the man himself. And
939987 [45028] what right had he to criticise him in that hasty and unguarded manner?
939987 [45029] Who had asked for his opinion? Was it thinkable that such a creature as
939987 [45030] Avdotya Romanovna would be marrying an unworthy man for money? So there
939987 [45031] must be something in him. The lodgings? But after all how could he know
939987 [45032] the character of the lodgings? He was furnishing a flat... Foo! how
939987 [45033] despicable it all was! And what justification was it that he was drunk?
939987 [45034] Such a stupid excuse was even more degrading! In wine is truth, and the
939987 [45035] truth had all come out, "that is, all the uncleanness of his coarse
939987 [45036] and envious heart"! And would such a dream ever be permissible to
939987 [45037] him, Razumihin? What was he beside such a girl--he, the drunken noisy
939987 [45038] braggart of last night? Was it possible to imagine so absurd and cynical
939987 [45039] a juxtaposition? Razumihin blushed desperately at the very idea and
939987 [45040] suddenly the recollection forced itself vividly upon him of how he had
939987 [45041] said last night on the stairs that the landlady would be jealous of
939987 [45042] Avdotya Romanovna... that was simply intolerable. He brought his fist
939987 [45043] down heavily on the kitchen stove, hurt his hand and sent one of the
939987 [45044] bricks flying.
939987 [45045] 
939987 [45046] "Of course," he muttered to himself a minute later with a feeling of
939987 [45047] self-abasement, "of course, all these infamies can never be wiped out or
939987 [45048] smoothed over... and so it's useless even to think of it, and I must
939987 [45049] go to them in silence and do my duty... in silence, too... and not ask
939987 [45050] forgiveness, and say nothing... for all is lost now!"
939987 [45051] 
939987 [45052] And yet as he dressed he examined his attire more carefully than usual.
939987 [45053] He hadn't another suit--if he had had, perhaps he wouldn't have put it
939987 [45054] on. "I would have made a point of not putting it on." But in any case he
939987 [45055] could not remain a cynic and a dirty sloven; he had no right to offend
939987 [45056] the feelings of others, especially when they were in need of his
939987 [45057] assistance and asking him to see them. He brushed his clothes carefully.
939987 [45058] His linen was always decent; in that respect he was especially clean.
939987 [45059] 
939987 [45060] He washed that morning scrupulously--he got some soap from Nastasya--he
939987 [45061] washed his hair, his neck and especially his hands. When it came to the
939987 [45062] question whether to shave his stubbly chin or not (Praskovya Pavlovna
939987 [45063] had capital razors that had been left by her late husband), the question
939987 [45064] was angrily answered in the negative. "Let it stay as it is! What if

939987 [45067]

939987 [45078] He was engaged in such monologues when Zossimov, who had spent the night

939987 [45080]

939987 [45083] Zossimov gave orders that they shouldn't wake him and promised to see

939987 [45085] 
939987 [45086] "If he is still at home," he added. "Damn it all! If one can't control

939987 [45089]

939987 [47828] painful. And still the same hush. Suddenly he heard a momentary sharp

939987 [47839] to say she did not stir, as though she were made of wood. He was

939987 [47841] bent her head lower. He bent right down to the ground and peeped up

939987 [47846] whispering within. He was overcome with frenzy and he began hitting the

939987 [47849] woman was simply shaking with mirth. He was rushing away, but the
939987 [47850] passage was full of people, the doors of the flats stood open and on the

939987 [47852] heads, all looking, but huddled together in silence and expectation.
939987 [47853] Something gripped his heart, his legs were rooted to the spot, they

939987 [50848] 
939987 [50849] 
939987 [50850] CHAPTER VI
939987 [50851] 
939987 [50852] When he remembered the scene afterwards, this is how Raskolnikov saw it.

939987 [50875] This man's appearance was at first sight very strange. He stared

939987 [51232] The morning that followed the fateful interview with Dounia and

939987 [51349] Andrey Semyonovitch was an anÃ¦mic, scrofulous little man, with strangely

939987 [51359] half-educated coxcombs, who attach themselves to the idea most in
939987 [51360] fashion only to vulgarise it and who caricature every cause they serve,
939987 [51361] however sincerely.
939987 [51362] 
939987 [51363] Though Lebeziatnikov was so good-natured, he, too, was beginning to

939987 [51744] "Yes, she is. For she is credulous and good-hearted, and she believes

939987 [51800] 
939987 [51801] All this time Lebeziatnikov had stood at the window or walked about the
939987 [51802] room, anxious not to interrupt the conversation; when Sonia had gone he

939987 [51804]

939987 [51829] "Because I don't want in your free marriage to be made a fool of and

939987 [51832] 
939987 [51833] He seemed preoccupied by something.

939987 [51869] 
939987 [51870] CHAPTER II
939987 [51871] 
939987 [51872] It would be difficult to explain exactly what could have originated the
939987 [51873] idea of that senseless dinner in Katerina Ivanovna's disordered brain.
939987 [51874] Nearly ten of the twenty roubles, given by Raskolnikov for Marmeladov's
939987 [51875] funeral, were wasted upon it. Possibly Katerina Ivanovna felt obliged to
939987 [51876] honour the memory of the deceased "suitably," that all the lodgers,
939987 [51877] and still more Amalia Ivanovna, might know "that he was in no way their
939987 [51878] inferior, and perhaps very much their superior," and that no one had the
939987 [51879] right "to turn up his nose at him." Perhaps the chief element was that
939987 [51880] peculiar "poor man's pride," which compels many poor people to spend
939987 [51881] their last savings on some traditional social ceremony, simply in order
939987 [51882] to do "like other people," and not to "be looked down upon." It is very
939987 [51883] probable, too, that Katerina Ivanovna longed on this occasion, at
939987 [51884] the moment when she seemed to be abandoned by everyone, to show those
939987 [51885] "wretched contemptible lodgers" that she knew "how to do things, how
939987 [51886] to entertain" and that she had been brought up "in a genteel, she might
939987 [51887] almost say aristocratic colonel's family" and had not been meant for
939987 [51888] sweeping floors and washing the children's rags at night. Even the
939987 [51889] poorest and most broken-spirited people are sometimes liable to these
939987 [51890] paroxysms of pride and vanity which take the form of an irresistible
939987 [51891] nervous craving. And Katerina Ivanovna was not broken-spirited; she
939987 [51892] might have been killed by circumstance, but her spirit could not have
939987 [51893] been broken, that is, she could not have been intimidated, her will
939987 [51894] could not be crushed. Moreover Sonia had said with good reason that her
939987 [51895] mind was unhinged. She could not be said to be insane, but for a year
939987 [51896] past she had been so harassed that her mind might well be overstrained.
939987 [51897] The later stages of consumption are apt, doctors tell us, to affect the
939987 [51898] intellect.
939987 [51899] 
939987 [51900] There was no great variety of wines, nor was there Madeira; but wine
939987 [51901] there was. There was vodka, rum and Lisbon wine, all of the poorest
939987 [51902] quality but in sufficient quantity. Besides the traditional rice and
939987 [51903] honey, there were three or four dishes, one of which consisted of
939987 [51904] pancakes, all prepared in Amalia Ivanovna's kitchen. Two samovars were
939987 [51905] boiling, that tea and punch might be offered after dinner. Katerina
939987 [51906] Ivanovna had herself seen to purchasing the provisions, with the help
939987 [51907] of one of the lodgers, an unfortunate little Pole who had somehow been
939987 [51908] stranded at Madame Lippevechsel's. He promptly put himself at Katerina
939987 [51909] Ivanovna's disposal and had been all that morning and all the day before
939987 [51910] running about as fast as his legs could carry him, and very anxious
939987 [51911] that everyone should be aware of it. For every trifle he ran to Katerina
939987 [51912] Ivanovna, even hunting her out at the bazaar, at every instant called
939987 [51913] her "_Pani_." She was heartily sick of him before the end, though
939987 [51914] she had declared at first that she could not have got on without this
939987 [51915] "serviceable and magnanimous man." It was one of Katerina Ivanovna's
939987 [51916] characteristics to paint everyone she met in the most glowing colours.
939987 [51917] Her praises were so exaggerated as sometimes to be embarrassing; she
939987 [51918] would invent various circumstances to the credit of her new acquaintance
939987 [51919] and quite genuinely believe in their reality. Then all of a sudden she
939987 [51920] would be disillusioned and would rudely and contemptuously repulse the
939987 [51921] person she had only a few hours before been literally adoring. She
939987 [51922] was naturally of a gay, lively and peace-loving disposition, but from
939987 [51923] continual failures and misfortunes she had come to desire so _keenly_
939987 [51924] that all should live in peace and joy and should not _dare_ to break the
939987 [51925] peace, that the slightest jar, the smallest disaster reduced her almost
939987 [51926] to frenzy, and she would pass in an instant from the brightest hopes and
939987 [51927] fancies to cursing her fate and raving, and knocking her head against
939987 [51928] the wall.
939987 [51929] 
939987 [51930] Amalia Ivanovna, too, suddenly acquired extraordinary importance in
939987 [51931] Katerina Ivanovna's eyes and was treated by her with extraordinary
939987 [51932] respect, probably only because Amalia Ivanovna had thrown herself heart
939987 [51933] and soul into the preparations. She had undertaken to lay the table,
939987 [51934] to provide the linen, crockery, etc., and to cook the dishes in her
939987 [51935] kitchen, and Katerina Ivanovna had left it all in her hands and gone
939987 [51936] herself to the cemetery. Everything had been well done. Even the
939987 [51937] table-cloth was nearly clean; the crockery, knives, forks and glasses
939987 [51938] were, of course, of all shapes and patterns, lent by different lodgers,
939987 [51939] but the table was properly laid at the time fixed, and Amalia Ivanovna,
939987 [51940] feeling she had done her work well, had put on a black silk dress and
939987 [51941] a cap with new mourning ribbons and met the returning party with some
939987 [51942] pride. This pride, though justifiable, displeased Katerina Ivanovna for
939987 [51943] some reason: "as though the table could not have been laid except by
939987 [51944] Amalia Ivanovna!" She disliked the cap with new ribbons, too. "Could she
939987 [51945] be stuck up, the stupid German, because she was mistress of the house,
939987 [51946] and had consented as a favour to help her poor lodgers! As a favour!
939987 [51947] Fancy that! Katerina Ivanovna's father who had been a colonel and almost
939987 [51948] a governor had sometimes had the table set for forty persons, and then
939987 [51949] anyone like Amalia Ivanovna, or rather Ludwigovna, would not have been
939987 [51950] allowed into the kitchen."
939987 [51951] 
939987 [51952] Katerina Ivanovna, however, put off expressing her feelings for the

939987 [51956] fancying herself. Katerina Ivanovna was irritated too by the fact that

939987 [51978] Among those who failed to appear were "the genteel lady and her

939987 [52025] Raskolnikov came in almost at the moment of their return from the

939987 [54242] CHAPTER I
939987 [54243] 
939987 [54244] A strange period began for Raskolnikov: it was as though a fog had
939987 [54245] fallen upon him and wrapped him in a dreary solitude from which there
939987 [54246] was no escape. Recalling that period long after, he believed that his
939987 [54247] mind had been clouded at times, and that it had continued so, with
939987 [54248] intervals, till the final catastrophe. He was convinced that he had been
939987 [54249] mistaken about many things at that time, for instance as to the date
939987 [54250] of certain events. Anyway, when he tried later on to piece his
939987 [54251] recollections together, he learnt a great deal about himself from what
939987 [54252] other people told him. He had mixed up incidents and had explained
939987 [54253] events as due to circumstances which existed only in his imagination. At
939987 [54254] times he was a prey to agonies of morbid uneasiness, amounting sometimes
939987 [54255] to panic. But he remembered, too, moments, hours, perhaps whole days,
939987 [54256] of complete apathy, which came upon him as a reaction from his previous
939987 [54257] terror and might be compared with the abnormal insensibility, sometimes
939987 [54258] seen in the dying. He seemed to be trying in that latter stage to escape
939987 [54259] from a full and clear understanding of his position. Certain essential
939987 [54260] facts which required immediate consideration were particularly irksome
939987 [54261] to him. How glad he would have been to be free from some cares, the
939987 [54262] neglect of which would have threatened him with complete, inevitable
939987 [54263] ruin.
939987 [54264] 
939987 [54265] He was particularly worried about SvidrigaÃ¯lov, he might be said to be
939987 [54266] permanently thinking of SvidrigaÃ¯lov. From the time of SvidrigaÃ¯lov's
939987 [54267] too menacing and unmistakable words in Sonia's room at the moment of
939987 [54268] Katerina Ivanovna's death, the normal working of his mind seemed to
939987 [54269] break down. But although this new fact caused him extreme uneasiness,
939987 [54270] Raskolnikov was in no hurry for an explanation of it. At times, finding
939987 [54271] himself in a solitary and remote part of the town, in some wretched
939987 [54272] eating-house, sitting alone lost in thought, hardly knowing how he had
939987 [54273] come there, he suddenly thought of SvidrigaÃ¯lov. He recognised
939987 [54274] suddenly, clearly, and with dismay that he ought at once to come to an
939987 [54275] understanding with that man and to make what terms he could. Walking
939987 [54276] outside the city gates one day, he positively fancied that they had
939987 [54277] fixed a meeting there, that he was waiting for SvidrigaÃ¯lov. Another
939987 [54278] time he woke up before daybreak lying on the ground under some bushes
939987 [54279] and could not at first understand how he had come there.
939987 [54280] 
939987 [54281] But during the two or three days after Katerina Ivanovna's death, he
939987 [54282] had two or three times met SvidrigaÃ¯lov at Sonia's lodging, where he
939987 [54283] had gone aimlessly for a moment. They exchanged a few words and made no
939987 [54284] reference to the vital subject, as though they were tacitly agreed not

939987 [54286] 
939987 [54287] Katerina Ivanovna's body was still lying in the coffin, SvidrigaÃ¯lov was

939987 [54289] their last meeting SvidrigaÃ¯lov informed Raskolnikov that he had made

939987 [54294] on them had been of great assistance, as it is much easier to place

939987 [54300] This conversation took place in the passage on the stairs. SvidrigaÃ¯lov

939987 [54309] He moved to one side to make way for the priest and server, who

939987 [54321] 
939987 [54322] "These last two days she hasn't said a word to me, she hasn't glanced at

939987 [54343] easier and even more solitary. One day at dusk he sat for an hour

939987 [54349] requiring immediate decision, but it was something he could not clearly
939987 [54350] understand or put into words. It was a hopeless tangle. "No, better the
939987 [54351] struggle again! Better Porfiry again... or SvidrigaÃ¯lov.... Better some

939987 [57989] Siberia. On the banks of a broad solitary river stands a town, one of
939987 [57990] the administrative centres of Russia; in the town there is a fortress,
939987 [57991] in the fortress there is a prison. In the prison the second-class
939987 [57992] convict Rodion Raskolnikov has been confined for nine months. Almost a
939987 [57993] year and a half has passed since his crime.
939987 [57994] 
939987 [57995] There had been little difficulty about his trial. The criminal adhered
939987 [57996] exactly, firmly, and clearly to his statement. He did not confuse nor
939987 [57997] misrepresent the facts, nor soften them in his own interest, nor omit
939987 [57998] the smallest detail. He explained every incident of the murder, the
939987 [57999] secret of _the pledge_ (the piece of wood with a strip of metal) which
939987 [58000] was found in the murdered woman's hand. He described minutely how he
939987 [58001] had taken her keys, what they were like, as well as the chest and its
939987 [58002] contents; he explained the mystery of Lizaveta's murder; described how
939987 [58003] Koch and, after him, the student knocked, and repeated all they had said
939987 [58004] to one another; how he afterwards had run downstairs and heard Nikolay
939987 [58005] and Dmitri shouting; how he had hidden in the empty flat and afterwards
939987 [58006] gone home. He ended by indicating the stone in the yard off the
939987 [58007] Voznesensky Prospect under which the purse and the trinkets were found.
939987 [58008] The whole thing, in fact, was perfectly clear. The lawyers and the
939987 [58009] judges were very much struck, among other things, by the fact that he
939987 [58010] had hidden the trinkets and the purse under a stone, without making
939987 [58011] use of them, and that, what was more, he did not now remember what the
939987 [58012] trinkets were like, or even how many there were. The fact that he had
939987 [58013] never opened the purse and did not even know how much was in it seemed
939987 [58014] incredible. There turned out to be in the purse three hundred and
939987 [58015] seventeen roubles and sixty copecks. From being so long under the stone,
939987 [58016] some of the most valuable notes lying uppermost had suffered from the
939987 [58017] damp. They were a long while trying to discover why the accused man
939987 [58018] should tell a lie about this, when about everything else he had made
939987 [58019] a truthful and straightforward confession. Finally some of the lawyers
939987 [58020] more versed in psychology admitted that it was possible he had really
939987 [58021] not looked into the purse, and so didn't know what was in it when he
939987 [58022] hid it under the stone. But they immediately drew the deduction that
939987 [58023] the crime could only have been committed through temporary mental
939987 [58024] derangement, through homicidal mania, without object or the pursuit of
939987 [58025] gain. This fell in with the most recent fashionable theory of temporary
939987 [58026] insanity, so often applied in our days in criminal cases. Moreover
939987 [58027] Raskolnikov's hypochondriacal condition was proved by many witnesses, by
939987 [58028] Dr. Zossimov, his former fellow students, his landlady and her servant.
939987 [58029] All this pointed strongly to the conclusion that Raskolnikov was not
939987 [58030] quite like an ordinary murderer and robber, but that there was another
939987 [58031] element in the case.

939987 [58274] He was ill a long time. But it was not the horrors of prison life, not
939987 [58275] the hard labour, the bad food, the shaven head, or the patched clothes

939987 [58279] him--the thin cabbage soup with beetles floating in it? In the past as a
939987 [58280] student he had often not had even that. His clothes were warm and suited
939987 [58281] to his manner of life. He did not even feel the fetters. Was he ashamed
939987 [58282] of his shaven head and parti-coloured coat? Before whom? Before Sonia?
939987 [58283] Sonia was afraid of him, how could he be ashamed before her? And yet he
939987 [58284] was ashamed even before Sonia, whom he tortured because of it with

939987 [58286] fetters he was ashamed of: his pride had been stung to the quick. It was
939987 [58287] wounded pride that made him ill. Oh, how happy he would have been if he
939987 [58288] could have blamed himself! He could have borne anything then, even

939987 [58290] conscience found no particularly terrible fault in his past, except
939987 [58291] a simple _blunder_ which might happen to anyone. He was ashamed just

939987 [58293] through some decree of blind fate, and must humble himself and submit to
939987 [58294] "the idiocy" of a sentence, if he were anyhow to be at peace.

939987 [58301] in order to exist? Why, he had been ready a thousand times before to
939987 [58302] give up existence for the sake of an idea, for a hope, even for a fancy.
939987 [58303] Mere existence had always been too little for him; he had always wanted
939987 [58304] more. Perhaps it was just because of the strength of his desires that he
939987 [58305] had thought himself a man to whom more was permissible than to others.
